poster="http://v.politico.com/images/1155968404/201804/1949/1155968404_5768295623001_5767689212001-vs.jpg?pubId=1155968404" true Mark Zuckerberg said that he's not aware of any additional third-party information mishandling, but that the company is conducting audits.

In an exchange with Rep. Anna Eshoo (D-Calif.) about the Cambridge Analytica data controversy, Eshoo asked Zuckerberg if he is "aware of other third-party information mishandlings that have not been disclosed."
The social network said last week that as many as 87 million users' data could have been improperly obtained by Cambridge Analytica, which did work for President Donald Trump's election campaign.

Zuckerberg says his own data sold to third parties

Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg Wednesday said his own personal data was sold to what a lawmaker called "malicious third parties."
Eshoo then moved on to other questions without confirming if Zuckerberg meant his information was swept up by Cambridge Analytica.

Story Continued Below

Zuckerberg said that he's not aware of any but that the company is conducting audits.
Eshoo followed up by asking, "Was your data included in the data sold to the malicious third parties?"
Facebook declined to clarify Zuckerberg's remarks.
